doc.title: Monthly GS Trimmed Core Declines Outside Japan (Peters)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/G10 Inflation Monitor Monthly GS Trimmed Core Declines Outside Japan Peters PetersG10 Inflation Monitor Monthly GS Trimm_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Our July sequential trimmed core inflation measures increased in Japan (2.1% month- over- month annualized vs. 1.7%) but ticked down in Canada (1.6% vs. 2.9%), the UK (2.4% vs. 3.6%), the US (2.1%, GS forecast for PCE, vs. 2.8%), and the Euro area (2.5% vs. 2.6%).

On a 3- month annualized basis, our trimmed core measures edged up in the UK (3.0% vs. 2.8%) and Euro area (2.4% vs. 2.3%) but declined in Canada (2.2% vs. 3.1%), Japan (1.8% vs. 2.1%), and the US (2.2%, GS forecast for PCE, vs. 2.4%).
The weighted median month- over- month core inflation rate ticked up in the Euro area but declined elsewhere.

The share of the headline basket running above 4% on a six- month annualized basis continued to increase in Canada to 53% (vs. 49%) but declined in Japan (32% vs. 40%), the US (CPI, 35% vs. 41%), the UK (42.3% vs. 46.5%), and the Euro area (21% vs. 24%). Extreme price movements remain less common, with the share of the headline basket exceeding an 8% annualized pace standing below 10% in the Euro area, the US, and the UK, and edging down to 15% in Japan and 16% in Canada.
The distribution of three- month inflation rates across items continued to shift back towards pre- pandemic norms in most economies, most notably in the US, but remains more dispersed in Canada.

On a 3- month annualized basis, core goods inflation accelerated in the Euro area (1.5% vs. 0.4%), US (1.5% vs. 0.9%), and UK (2.5% vs. 2.2%), moved sideways in Canada (2.8%), and slowed in Japan (5.3% vs. 6.7%). Core services inflation ticked down in the UK (2.9% vs. 5.7%), Euro area (1.8% vs. 3.8%), and Canada (2.3% vs. 3.5%), but increased in Japan (1.8% vs. 1.4%) and the US (3.2% vs. 2.9%).
On a 3- month annualized basis, rent inflation slowed in Canada (4.2% vs. 5.1%),
the US (2.8% vs. 3.2%), the Euro area (2.9% vs. 3.0%), and Japan (0.4% vs. 0.5%) and moved sideways in the UK (2.0%).

- On a 3-month annualized basis, energy inflation declined in Japan (-9.3% vs. 2.1%), the US (-4.3% vs. 2.5%), and the UK (-3.2% vs. -0.4%), but ticked up from depressed levels in Canada and the Euro area. Food inflation accelerated across DMs.
- In July, year-over-year core inflation surprised to the upside again in the UK, largely driven by airfares. Core inflation was in line with consensus expectations elsewhere.

- On a 3-month average annualized basis, traditional exclusion-based core inflation has moderated from its cyclical peak by 6.3pp in the UK, 5.4pp in the Euro area, 5.3pp in Canada, and 3.7pp in the US. In Japan, three-month annualized core inflation is now only 2.3pp below its peak. On a year-over-year basis, traditional core inflation has declined by 3.4pp in the Euro area, 3.3pp in the UK, 3.0pp in Canada, 2.7pp in the US, and 0.9pp in Japan.

- We forecast that year-over-year core inflation will climb to +3.2% in the US, reflecting price pressures from tariffs. Elsewhere, we expect core inflation to moderate to +3.7% in the UK, +3.0% in Canada, +2.2% in Japan, and +2.0% in the Euro area.

- Over the last month, we revised up our core and headline inflation forecasts in the UK by 0.2pp, partly driven by a firmer outlook for food inflation in H2 than we previously assumed. In Canada, we revised down our forecast for headline inflation by 0.2pp following the removal of retaliatory tariffs on USMCA compliant goods and a softer July print.

- Traditional core inflation measures preferred by major central banks differ in terms of included categories and measurement approaches. We previously documented these differences and constructed harmonized core inflation measures to help compare like-for-like inflation trends across countries.- On a 3-month basis, our harmonized core measures are generally slightly lower than the central banks' preferred core measures. In the Euro area, this largely reflects the exclusion of food away from home, which remains elevated. In Japan, the divergence was driven by firm inflation for non-fresh food and alcoholic beverages, which are included in new core CPI but which we exclude from our harmonized measure.
Exhibit 1: On a Monthly Annualized Basis, Our GS Trimmed Core Inflation Increased in Japan but Declined Elsewhere

May 2025 Undriving Inflation Measures% change, month ago annualized% change, 3 month ago annualized% change, year agoGS TrimmedGS SummaryTraditional CoreGS TrimmedGS SummaryTraditional CoreGS TrimmedTraditional CoreUS*2.072.293.172.192.202.962.472.49Euro Area2.462.082.242.371.961.672.291.98Japan2.062.301.092.822.383.331.812.41UK2.412.244.003.023.013.023.373.39Canada1.571.210.782.201.492.092.942.43DMs**2.112.032.382.312.212.612.572.54

GS summary core inflation is a PCA- weighted average of our trimmed, cyclical, and persistent core inflation measures. For further details, see Sid Bhushan and Christian Schnittker, "Fimer Underlying Inflation, Faster Normalization", Global Economics Analyst, 30 January 2022. GS trimmed core systematically trims a weighted one- third of month- to- month changes across all core inflation categories and then takes the weighted average of the remaining two- thirds. We determine how much of that one- third to trim off the top and off the bottom to generate the same average inflation rate as the traditional core inflation index. Traditional core measure is PCE ex. food and energy in the US, HICP ex. food, energy, alcohol and tobacco in the Euro area, CPI ex. food, energy, alcohol and tobacco in the UK, CPI ex. fresh food and energy in Japan, and CPI ex. food and energy in Canada.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: On a 3-Month Annualized Basis, GS Trimmed Core Inflation Declined Outside of the UK and Euro Area

GS trimmed core systematicaly trms a weighted one- third of month- to- month changes across all core inflation categories and then takes the weighted average of the remaining two- thirds. We determine how much of that one- third to trim off the top and off the bottom to generate the same average inflation rate as the traditional core inflation index. \\*July US PCE is a GS forecast.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: Our GS Trimmed Core Year-Over-Year Inflation Rate Stands at \(+3.4\%\) in the UK, \(+2.9\%\) in Canada, \(+2.5\%\) in the US, \(+2.3\%\) in the Euro Area and \(+1.8\%\) in Japan

GS trimmed core systematicaly trims a weighted one- third of month- to- month changes across all core inflation categories and then takes the weighted average of the remaining two- thirds. We determine how much of that one- third to trim off the top and off the bottom to generate the same average inflation rate as the traditional core inflation index. Traditional core measure is PCE ex. food and energy in the US, HICP ex. food, energy, alcohol and tobacco in the Euro Area, CPI ex. food, energy, alcohol and tobacco in the UK, CPI ex. fresh food and energy in Japan, and CPI ex. food and energy in Canada. \*July US PCE is a GS forecast.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 4: Weighted Median Month-Over-Month Core Inflation Ticked Up in the Euro Area but Declined Elsewhere
*July US PCE is a GS forecast.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 5: On a 6-Month Annualized Basis, the Share of the Headline Inflation Basket Running Above \(4\%\) Continued to Edge Up in Canada But Moderated in Other DMs
\\*July US PCE is a GS forecast.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: The Distribution of Three-Month Inflation Rates Has Shifted Back Close to the Pre-Pandemic Norm, Especially in the US
Peak refers to the month where the median three-month rate reached its highest level since Jan 2021. \\*July US PCE is a GS forecast.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 7: The Share of the Basket Showing Increasing Inflation on a Year-over-Year Basis Declined in Japan and Canada but Ticked Up in the UK
Source:Haver Analytics,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 9: On a 3-Month Annualized Basis, Rent Inflation Slowed or Moved Sideways Across DMs

Cross-country differences in the persistence of rent inflation may also reflect differences in the methodology employed to measure rent changes. Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 10: Energy Inflation Declined in Japan, the US and the UK; Food Inflation Accelerated Across DMs
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 11: On a 3- Month Annualized Basis, Traditional Core Inflation Has Declined by Around 6pp Relative to Its Peak in the UK, by 5pp in Canada and the Euro Area, and by 4pp in the US
For each inflation measure, we plot the latest value available and the maximum value observed since January 2022. \\*The latest values for US PCE are GS forecasts.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: Our End-25 Core Inflation Forecasts Are Generally Below Consensus
\\*The latest values for US PCE are GS forecasts.
Source: Haver Analytics, Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
